content: The "Internet Gambling Regulation and Tax Enforcement Act of 2008" is a new law that amends the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It introduces a license fee for internet gambling operators and requires them to report licensee information. The "Internet Gambling Regulation and Tax Enforcement Act of 2008" introduces a new subchapter imposing a license fee on internet gambling operators. The Internet Gambling Regulation and Tax Enforcement Act of 2008 requires licensed internet gambling operators to pay a 2 percent license fee on all funds deposited into accounts used for betting or wagering. Winnings deposits are excluded from this fee. The Internet gambling license fee is 2 percent of all funds deposited into accounts for betting. The fees are deposited into the Treasury's general fund as revenue and are the exclusive obligation of the licensee. The Internet gambling license fees are deposited into the Treasury's general fund as revenue and are the exclusive obligation of the licensee. The Director is defined as per section 5382 of title 31, United States Code. The Internet gambling license fees are deposited into the Treasury's general fund as revenue and are the exclusive obligation of the licensee. The term 'Director' is defined as per section 5382 of title 31, United States Code. The Internet gambling license fee may be treated as an excise tax for administrative purposes. The Internet gambling license fee is considered an excise tax for administrative purposes. Information Returns section is amended to include provisions for persons subject to special regulations. "SEC. 6039J. RETURNS OF INTERNET GAMBLING OPERATORS." Every Internet gambling operator subject to section 4491 must provide required information to the Secretary as prescribed by regulations, and maintain appropriate records. The information includes the operator's name, address, and other details determined by the Secretary. The Internet gambling operator must provide required information to the Secretary, including the operator's name, address, tax information number, and details of each person placing wagers, gross winnings, wagers, and losses. The Internet gambling operator must provide the Secretary with the name, address, and tax information number, as well as details of each person placing wagers, including gross winnings, wagers, and losses, tax withheld, account balances, and amounts deposited and withdrawn during the year. The Internet gambling operator must provide the Secretary with tax information for each person placing wagers, including gross winnings, wagers, losses, tax withheld, account balances, and amounts deposited and withdrawn during the year. Additionally, every person required to make a return must furnish a written statement to each person with their name, address, and contact information. Every person required to make a return must provide a written statement to each person with their name, address, and contact information by January 31 of the following year. The written statement required for tax returns must be provided to individuals by January 31 of the following year. Amendments are made to the table of subchapters for chapter 36. Amendments are made to the table of sections for internet gambling operators, with a new item added for returns of Internet gambling operators. The effective date for these amendments is after December 31, 2008. Additionally, withholding from certain gambling winnings is addressed in Section 3. Amendments to section 3402(q) include withholding on net Internet gambling winnings over $5,000 in a calendar year and no exemption for these winnings. Definitions in subsection (q) are also updated. Amendments to section 3402(q) include withholding on net Internet gambling winnings over $5,000 in a calendar year and no exemption for these winnings. Definitions in subsection (q) are also updated to include the term 'proceeds of net Internet gambling winnings'. The term 'proceeds of net Internet gambling winnings' refers to amounts withdrawn from an account established for Internet gambling, while 'net Internet gambling winnings' are gross winnings from wagers placed online with licensed entities. The term 'net Internet gambling winnings' refers to gross winnings from online wagers with licensed entities, excluding the amount wagered. The terms 'Internet' and 'wager' are defined in section 5382 of chapter 53 of title 31, United States Code. The amendment includes defining terms related to Internet gambling and treating net Internet gambling winnings as reportable payments for backup withholding purposes. The amendment defines terms for Internet gambling, treats net Internet gambling winnings as reportable payments for backup withholding, and applies to wagers placed after December 31, 2008. SEC. 4. WITHHOLDING OF TAX ON NONRESIDENT ALIENS. Tax on Nonresident Alien Individuals is amended to include net Internet gambling income. An exemption for certain gambling winnings now includes wagers placed over the Internet. The amendment includes net Internet gambling winnings in the tax on nonresident alien individuals. An exemption for certain gambling winnings now covers wagers placed over the Internet. The amendment to section 1441 includes net Internet gambling winnings over $5,000 in the tax on nonresident aliens, effective for wagers placed after December 31, 2008. SEC. 5. TAX ON WAGERS. Amendments to tax laws regarding wagers include holding individuals accountable for placing wagers with unlicensed entities and specifying the territorial extent of wagers placed by US citizens or residents. The amendments to tax laws regarding wagers specify that US citizens or residents must pay taxes on wagers placed within the United States or its territories after December 31, 2008.
